title: 108_hr4915
content: The "Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004" is cited as the short title. It introduces an exclusion for gain from stock of small, publicly traded companies in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004 excludes gain from the sale of section 1203 stock held for over a year for non-corporate taxpayers. The exclusion is limited to $100,000 ($50,000 for married individuals filing separately). 1203 stock refers to stock in a C corporation acquired after the enactment date if the corporation is a qualified small business at the time of acquisition. The term "stock" refers to stock in a C corporation acquired after the enactment date if the corporation is a qualified small business at the time of acquisition, and the stock is acquired in exchange for money, property, or as compensation for services provided to the corporation. The term "stock" in a C corporation refers to stock acquired after the enactment date in exchange for money, property, or as compensation for services provided to the corporation. The stock must be publicly traded on a domestic stock exchange, Over the Counter Bulletin Board, or National Quotation Bureau for gain exclusion under subsection (a). The term "qualified small business" refers to a domestic C corporation with a market capitalization not exceeding $150,000,000 at the time of stock acquisition. The market capitalization of a qualified small business, or any predecessor, must not exceed $150,000,000 at the time of stock acquisition. Market capitalization is determined by the closing price of a share of stock in the corporation at the end of the reporting period before the acquisition date. The market capitalization of a qualified small business is determined by the closing price of a share of stock at the end of the reporting period before the acquisition date, multiplied by the number of outstanding shares of such stock. If this method does not apply, market capitalization is determined based on the most recent amounts paid for each class of stock in the corporation. The market capitalization of a qualified small business is determined by the closing price of a share of stock at the end of the reporting period before the acquisition date, multiplied by the number of outstanding shares of such stock. If this method does not apply, market capitalization is determined based on the most recent amounts paid for each class of stock in the corporation outstanding on the date of the acquisition of the stock. The term 'reporting period' refers to the period for which the most recent annual or quarterly report is required to be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. The term 'reporting period' refers to the period for which the most recent annual or quarterly report is required to be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. Aggregation rules similar to section 1202(d)(3) apply for determining market capitalization of a qualified small business. Additional rules similar to subsections (f), (g), (h), (i), (j) are also applicable. Additional rules similar to subsections (f), (g), (h), (i), (j), and (k) of section 1202 apply, with a modification in subsection (j)(1)(A) where '1 year' is substituted for '5 years'. Sales and exchanges considered under section 1202 are not counted under this section. Conforming amendments are made to section 642(c)(4) of the Code. Conforming amendments are made to sections 642(c)(4), 643(a)(3), and 691(c)(4) of the Code regarding sections 1202 and 1203. Amendments are made to various sections of the Code, including 643(a)(3), 691(c)(4), and 871(a)(2), to include references to sections 1202 and 1203. Section 1044(d) is also modified to include reference to section 1203. Additionally, a new subsection is added to section 1202(b) of the Code. Amendments are made to section 1044(d) and 1202(b) of the Code, with section 1203 stock sales not affecting section 1202. A clerical amendment is also made to the table of sections. The amendments made by section 1203 provide an exclusion for gain from stock of small, publicly traded companies. This applies to securities acquired after the enactment of the Act.
